Text: Your tool for detecting internet censorship!
OONI Probe checks whether your provider blocks access to websites and apps. You can also measure your network's speed and performance.
Run OONI Probe to collect evidence of internet censorship!
Anyone monitoring your internet activity (such as your government or ISP) may be able to see that you are running OONI Probe.
The network data you collect will automatically get published (unless you opt-out in the settings).
Read the documentation to learn more.
Anyone monitoring my internet activity may be able to see that I am running OONI Probe.
OONI Probe is not a privacy tool. Anyone monitoring your internet activity may be able to see which software you are running.
The network data I collect will automatically get published (unless I opt-out in the settings).
The network data you collect will automatically get published (unless you opt-out in the settings) to increase transparency of internet censorship.
We do our best not to publish:
Measure whether websites are blocked using OONI's [Web Connectivity test](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/web-connectivity/). Tap the Configure button to choose which sites to test!
You will test sites listed [here](https://github.com/citizenlab/test-lists/tree/master/lists). The more times you run this test, the more sites you will test.
This test measures whether websites are blocked by means of DNS tampering, TCP/IP blocking or by a transparent HTTP proxy.
Your results will be published on [OONI Explorer](https://explorer.ooni.torproject.org/world/) and [OONI API](https://api.ooni.io/) (unless if you have opted-out).
Test your network speed and performance
Measure the speed and performance of your network using the [NDT](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/ndt/) and [DASH](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/dash/) tests.
Disclaimer: These tests rely on third party servers. We therefore cannot guarantee that your IP address will not be collected.
Your results will be published on [OONI Explorer](https://explorer.ooni.torproject.org/world/) and [OONI API](https://api.ooni.io/) (unless if you have opted-out).

Internet Service Providers often use network appliances, called middleboxes, for various networking purposes (such as caching). Sometimes these middleboxes are used to implement internet censorship and/or surveillance.

Find middleboxes in your network using OONI's [HTTP Invalid Request Line](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/http-invalid-request-line/) and [HTTP Header Field Manipulation](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/http-header-field-manipulation/) tests.
Your results will be published on [OONI Explorer](https://explorer.ooni.torproject.org/world/) and [OONI API](https://api.ooni.io/) (unless if you have opted-out).
Test the blocking of instant messaging apps
Your results will be published on [OONI Explorer](https://explorer.ooni.torproject.org/world/) and [OONI API](https://api.ooni.io/) (unless if you have opted-out).
No tests have been run yet. Try running one!
You can access {{WebsiteURL}} from this network.
Your Internet Service Provider is likely blocking access to {{WebsiteURL}} by means of {{BlockingReason}}.
Note: False positives can occur. Learn more [here](https://ooni.torproject.org/nettest/web-connectivity/).
HTTP blocking (a blockpage might be served)
Try visiting the HTTPS version of the site: (website with https).
Tor is the most effective tool for circumventing internet censorship. You can use Tor Browser on a laptop and on Android, and Onion Browser on iOS.
If torproject.org is blocked in your country, you can [download Tor from a mirror of it hosted on GitHub](https://github.com/TheTorProject/gettorbrowser).
Note: The above techniques might not always work.

The Open Observatory of Network Interference (OONI) is a free software project under The Tor Project that aims to increase transparency of internet censorship and other forms of network interference around the world.
Since 2012, OONI's global community has been measuring networks in more than 200 countries. Some of these measurements serve as evidence of internet censorship.
Click here to view OONI's Data Policy
This information (e.g. IT for Italy) is required to identify which country the measurements are collected from. Are you sure you want to disable this option?

By publishing results, you are increasing transparency of network interference and supporting the OONI community. Network information (i.e. Autonomous System Number) is required for identifying Internet Service Providers.

You will test a random sample of websites.
Sites devoted to the use and sale of drugs and alcohol.
Sites devoted to discussion of religious issues, both supportive and critical, as well as discussion of minority religious groups.
Sites which show provocative attire and portray women wearing minimal clothing.
Content that offers critical political viewpoints (e.g. oppositional political organizations, pro-democracy content, etc.).
Content that offers discussions on human rights issues. Includes women's rights and rights of minority ethnic groups.
Sites discussing environmental issues (e.g. pollution, international environmental treaties, deforestation, disasters, etc.).
Sites promoting terrorism, violent militant or separatist movements.
Content that disparages particular groups or persons based on race, sex, sexuality or other characteristics.
Major news websites (BBC, CNN, etc.) as well as regional news outlets and independent media.
Sites providing information on contraception, abstinence, STDs, healthy sexuality, teen pregnancy, rape prevention, abortion, sexual rights, and sexual health services.
Sites providing information on public health issues (e.g. HIV, SARS, bird flu, centers for disease control, World Health Organization, etc.).
Sites that provide tools for anonymization, censorship circumvention and encryption.
Online social networking tools and platforms.
Sites hosted by Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Intersex (LGBTQI) communities or discussing LGBTQI issues (excluding pornography).
Sites used to share files, including cloud-based file storage, torrents and P2P file-sharing tools.
Sites dedicated to computer security, including news and tools.
Sites and tools for individual and group communications (includes webmail, VoIP, instant messaging, chat and mobile messaging applications).
Video, audio and photo sharing platforms.
Web hosting services, blogging and other online publishing platforms.
Online games and gaming platforms (excluding gambling sites).
Content relating to entertainment, history, literature, music, film, books, satire and humour.
Sites discussing general economic development and poverty related topics.
Sites of commercial services and products.
Benign or innocuous content used as a control.
Sites of intergovernmental organizations, such as the United Nations.
Sites that haven't been categorized yet.
